column2: One winter evening, as soon as his work was over for the day, Joseph locked the door of his smithy, washed himself well, put on clean clothes, and, taking his violin, set out for Testbridge: Mary was expecting him to tea.

column2: It was the afternoon of a holiday, and she had closed early.
column3: It was the afternoon of a holiday, and she had closed early.

column2: His being was like an all-sided lens concentrating all joys in the one heart of his consciousness.
column3: His being was like an all sided lens concentrating all joys in the one heart of his consciousness.

column2: Earth was gone, and heaven was all.

column2: Through the kitchen to the parlor! he said.

column2: O my God--through the mud of me, up to thy righteousness!"

column2: He stepped across the floor, still, stately, and free.

column2: Letty, finding herself not quite equal to the emergency, came in her turn to call Mary: she went as quietly as if she were leaving a tiresome visitor.

column2: Mary had not listened long before she found herself strangely moved. Her heart seemed to swell up into her throat, and it was all she could do to keep from weeping.

column2: A little longer and she was compelled to yield, and the silent tears flowed freely.
column3: A little longer and she was compelled to yield, and the silent tears flowed freely.

column2: Letty, too, was overcome--more than ever she had been by music.

column2: A mood had taken shape in the mind of the blacksmith, and wandered from its home, seeking another country.
column3: A mood had taken shape in the mind of the blacksmith, and wandered from its home, seeking another country.

column2: Thus, in a garment of mood whose color and texture was music, did the soul of Joseph Jasper that evening, like a homeless ghost, come knocking at the door of Mary Marston.
column3: Thus, in a garment of mood whose color and texture was music, did the soul of Joseph Jasper that evening, like a homeless ghost, come knocking at the door of Mary Marston.

column2: It prayed, it wept, it implored.
column3: It prayed, it wept, it implored.

column2: It cried aloud that eternity was very long, and like a great palace without a quiet room.

column2: On the bough of an apple-tree, in the fair moonlight, sat a nightingale, swaying to and fro like one mad with the wine of his own music, singing as if he wanted to break his heart and have done, for the delight was too much for mortal creature to endure.

column2: His violin was broken, but his being was made whole! his treasure taken--type of his self, and a woman given him instead!
